report_title: Nursery & Garden Stores in the US
executive_summary:
Nursery and garden stores have experienced significant highs and lows over the past five years. Rising per capita disposable income and increased private spending on home improvements helped industry revenue stay strong during the pandemic. Meanwhile, individuals aged 35 and younger have expressed increased interest and demand for small plants, like succulents, to enhance the aesthetic of their living spaces. However, as inflation has increased and the number of housing starts has declined, operating costs have grown and commercial demand for plants has declined. As a result, nursery and garden store revenue is expected to decline at a CAGR of 0.1% through the end of 2024. Meanwhile, as operating costs remain high, profit is expected to drop to 4.3%.

External competition has threatened the industry over the past five years. Big-box retailers, like Home Depot and e-commerce companies like Amazon, have taken a large share of product demand. These stores offer low prices and convenient access to thousands of products. Still, nursery and garden stores have often been able to compensate for higher prices by offering more in-depth product knowledge and superior customer service. With competition on the rise, garden store revenue is expected to fall 1.4% to $43.2 billion in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Blossoming Demand for Nursery and Garden Stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising per capita disposable income and private spending on home improvement have enabled retailers to remain profitable. Even as economic conditions soured due to the COVID-19 pandemic, private spending on home improvements grew as consumers sought to upgrade their homes while spending an increasing portion of their time there.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: External Competition from Big-Box Stores is Threatening Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Home improvement stores, like Home Depot and Lowe's and mass merchandisers, like Walmart and Target, sell garden and farm equipment in a dedicated area. They source products at lower costs and pass on savings to consumers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Price Competition is a Defining Trait of the Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: When input prices rise, nurseries and garden centers absorb costs, as price increases often send consumers to non-industry retailers. With the high level of outside competition, garden stores must keep prices as low as possible. Garden stores often can't keep prices as low as big box retailers can. Retailers emphasize personalized services to compensate for their typically higher prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Shift Toward E-Commerce Drives Nursery & Garden Stores Industry
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rise of e-commerce platforms has significantly impacted the industry, enabling businesses to expand their market reach far beyond their physical location. More and more stores are maximizing their online presence through social media marketing, quickly reaching a wider consumer base. Consumers now prefer shopping for plants online due to convenience and variety compared to physical stores. Online sales have boosted revenue, making up for declines in brick-and-mortar stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: E-commerce and Big-Box Stores Will Continue to Compete With Nursery and Garden Stores
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As big-box stores continue offering lower prices, nursery and garden stores must strengthen their position in their local communities to compete. E-commerce companies will continue to direct sales to customers through online purchases, lowering demand for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Many Retailers Are Expected to Shift Their Focus to Higher-Margin Specialty Items
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Retailers will shift toward higher-margin specialty products like rare plant strains, environmentally friendly growing materials, and customizable accessories unavailable at a discount or big-box retailers to boost demand. Nursery and garden stores will prioritize creating an excellent customer service experience and hiring knowledgeable employees to differentiate themselves.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Retailers Will Likely Benefit From a Shift Toward Environmentally-Friendly Gardening Practices
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: With numerous droughts and wildfires, coupled with an overall cultural shift toward sustainability, environmentally friendly products will drive demand for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Urbanization Will Continue to Drive Demand for Indoor Gardening
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The popularity of indoor plants and urban gardening is rising, particularly among people in their 20s and 30s. This trend is driven by urbanization and a desire for green space in smaller indoor living environments. As urbanization continues, people living in apartments will look to plants to make their spaces more comfortable and improve the air quality in their homes. In response, nursery and garden stores will expand their range of indoor plants, pots and related supplies and focus more marketing efforts on this segment.

industry_definition: The industry primarily retails a broad range of nursery and garden products, including trees, shrubs, plants, seeds, bulbs and sod, to households and the farming community. This industry also includes stores that retail farm supplies like animal feed (excluding pet food). The growing and retailing of nursery stock are included in the Plant and Flower Growing industry (IBISWorld report 11142).

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: Nursery and garden stores are characterized by intense competition and a saturated and fragmented market. Retailers compete based on store location, price, product range and quality, customer service and additional services.
External competitors have diversified their offerings to include nursery and garden products. Home improvement stores and mass merchandisers have dedicated square footage to garden centers.

The household market has significantly affected nursery and garden stores' revenue growth. Rising per capita disposable income and falling unemployment have supported increased consumer spending over the past five years.

Big-box stores will continue to compete with nursery and garden stores. As big-box stores continue offering lower prices, nursery and garden stores must strengthen their position in their local communities to compete.
Most retailers are small- to medium-sized companies. Large retailers like Tractor Supply Company can realize significant cost savings because of the economies of scale.

Nursery and garden stores are subject to regulations related to fair trading practices, the environment and trust and labor laws. Many states require plant and nursery vendors to be licensed by the state government.
While tariffs apply to the goods this industry sells, they have little effect at the retail level. Retailers buy goods from wholesalers who import them after tariffs apply.
Individual companies' cost structures can vary greatly. The nature of the industry's various product lines and geographic-specific markets.

Competition in nursery and garden stores stifles profit. With rising competition from big-box stores and e-commerce services, retailers have had to price their items more competitively, limiting profit growth.

Like most retail industries, the geographic spread of garden stores largely reflects the distribution of the population. Weather conditions, housing density, farm distribution and average lawn acreage drive consumer demand for nursery and garden products.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Farmers are involved in agricultural activities, primarily crop cultivation and livestock raising. Many farmers purchase their lawn and garden goods in bulk from wholesalers or manufacturers. If a flood or drought diminishes farmers' outputs in a given year, they will substitute their crops and propagative materials with store-bought items.

Though fewer members of this age group are buying homes than their predecessors, many purchase small houseplants and succulents for their indoor living spaces. Over the past five years, this demographic has become increasingly important.

Consumers aged 35 to 54 have established careers, families and higher disposable income levels. Gardening is a pastime growing in popularity among this demographic, also expanding as the population ages. Because of COVID-19, this segment's revenue share has increased, prompting many people to take up new hobbies, like gardening.

Numerous consumers in this demographic are of retirement age and have more time to dedicate to leisure activities like gardening, yard maintenance and other do-it-yourself projects. According to the US Census, this group's homeownership rate is the highest of any US age demographic. So, many of these consumers have a yard or lawn to maintain.

Other retailers and wholesalers sell products to customers but differ in their distribution channels and target markets. This segment includes purchasing flowers, plants or other goods from nursery and garden stores to resell. The segment has maintained a stable revenue share over the past five years.

Building contractors, governmental bodies, manufacturers, restaurants and other businesses are responsible for the remaining revenue share. These businesses purchase industry goods for the aesthetic enhancement of their facilities, yard maintenance and hardware tools to make repairs.

products_and_services.product_description: The segment includes seeds, plants, soil, trees and fresh flowers. Consumer demand for home lawn and garden goods increased during the COVID-19 pandemic. The segment has maintained a stable revenue share over the past five years.

The segment includes hardware, electrical supplies, lawn and garden tools and spare equipment parts. Consumers turn to DIY home projects rather than hiring professionals to complete garden and lawn maintenance, increasing tool sales. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, consumers spend more time at home, creating an opportunity for this segment.

This segment includes the sale of automotive and household fuels. Automotive fuels are sold on a small scale to provide consumers with gasoline for small power mowers and other garden equipment. Many retailers also sell wood for consumers to purchase for at-home use, a product included in household fuels.

Many retailers sell small gifts, personal products and food items to create a more enjoyable and unique experience for consumers that helps them to compete with larger big-box retailers. The segment will boost as a share of revenue as retailers continue seeking ways to diversify revenue streams and remain competitive.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The agricultural price index represents prices received by farmers for all US agricultural products, including livestock and crops. As farmers represent the second-largest downstream market for the industry, trends in this driver have a significant positive influence over industry revenue. The agricultural price index will likely rise in 2023.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Do-it-yourself boosts demand for tools and equipment
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Consumers turn to DIY home projects rather than hiring professionals to complete garden and lawn maintenance, increasing tool sales.
Numerous consumers in this demographic are of retirement age and have more time to dedicate to leisure activities like gardening, yard maintenance and other DIY projects.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has a high concentration of establishments. Its mild winters make it a prime area for year-round gardening and farming. Florida accounts for the region's largest population and industry presence.

The Plains region has more industrial establishments than the population. The region's climate and flat land are ideal for agriculture, boosting demand for nursery stock. Texas has the most significant number of nursery and garden stores.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The most important laws under this category include Sherman Antitrust Act, Clayton Antitrust Act, Hart-Scott-Rodino Act and Robinson-Patman Act. Individual states also have antitrust laws to ensure consumers aren't disadvantaged concerning prices and competition between retailers.

Companies in the industry are subject to labor regulations. These regulations cover occupational health and safety, wage, overtime and other employment issues involving state and federal government agencies.

The ADA prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities in several areas, including employment, transportation, public accommodations, communications and access to state and local government programs and services. For the industry, stores must be accessible to customers with disabilities.

regulations_points.regulation_title: FEDERAL INSECTICIDE, FUNGICIDE, AND RODENTICIDE ACT (FIFRA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The FIFRA provides for federal pesticide distribution, sale and uses regulation. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires that all pesticides distributed or sold in the United States be registered.
The Wilson Tariff Act promotes trade and commerce by making it simpler and less expensive for foreign goods to enter the US market.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Nursery and garden stores are subject to regulations related to fair trading practices, the environment and trust and labor laws.
The initial cost of establishing retail outlets and purchasing inventory and the marketing costs associated with promoting a new business can be substantial for industry entrants.
Nursery and garden stores differentiate based on product type, price, retail model, or product knowledge and expertise.
Capital assets include sprinkler systems, greenhouses, humidity controls, store light fixtures, cash registers, point-of-sale (POS) systems and other equipment.

basis_points.basis_description: Retailers compete based on store location, price, product range and quality, customer service and additional services.
External competitors have diversified their offerings to include nursery and garden products.
Home improvement stores and mass merchandisers have dedicated square footage to garden centers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Nursery and garden stores are highly fragmented.
The industry has many small, independently-owned nurseries and garden centers, resulting in a low market share concentration.
Relatively low barriers to entry enable family-owned and operated stores to dominate specific geographic markets.
The existence of networks between retailers and suppliers makes it difficult for new entrants.
Since larger companies benefit from economies of scale, their purchasing power enables them to purchase large quantities in bulk at low prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs are the Largest Expense for the Industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Retailers purchase nursery and garden products from upstream wholesalers or manufacturers and resell them to final consumers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Commodity prices, particularly fuel costs, have trended downward
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Commodity prices, particularly fuel costs, have trended downward during the period, providing some relief to retailers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Garden centers are relatively labor-intensive. Still, capital assets include sprinkler systems, greenhouses, humidity controls, store light fixtures, cash registers, point-of-sale (POS) systems and other equipment.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Nursery and Garden Products are Considered Discretionary
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations primarily influence demand in the overall level of real household disposable income and consumer confidence.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Private investment in home improvement also affects potential sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Private investment in home improvement also affects potential sales because consumers often engage in gardening and landscaping projects to improve the resale value of their property.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Price Competition in Nursery and Garden Stores Increases Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Price competition is a defining industry trait, leaving little room for retailers to expand profit.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Retailers can manage inventory more efficiently by integrating a point-of-sale system (POS).
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Retailers can manage inventory more efficiently by integrating a point-of-sale system (POS).

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Retailers that integrate new technology can often rapidly adapt to changes in consumer demand.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Retailers that integrate new technology can often rapidly adapt to changes in consumer demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Online ordering options can help retailers expand their services and compete with e-commerce companies.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Online ordering options can help retailers expand their services and compete with e-commerce companies.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: This industry's sales are highly dependent on the health of the US economy. Sales are correlated with not only the level of disposable income but also housing starts and home remodeling, all of which are less likely to increase during periods of low economic activity.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Nursery and garden stores sell a diversified range of farm and garden maintenance products, including equipment, plants, machines, fertilizers and. Some stores focus on selling a specific range of products.

FAQs.question: Have rising input costs negatively affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuations in fuel costs can impact the transportation of goods, impacting both deliveries to customers and shipments from suppliers.

FAQs.question: Does your company lease equipment to reduce overhead costs?
FAQs.answer: Nursery and garden stores are not characterized by a high capital intensity nor are equipment costs high enough to warrant leasing equipment.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: While shipping plants are complex and governed by state regulations, online ordering options can help retailers expand their services and compete with e-commerce companies.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: Stores can use POS systems to manage their garden center or nursery inventories. POS systems are important for tracking inventory and sales trends to ensure that stores are able to keep popular items stocked.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: The Wilson Tariff Act promotes trade and commerce by making it simpler and less expensive for foreign goods to enter the US market. Individual states have antitrust laws to ensure consumers aren't disadvantaged concerning prices and competition between retailers.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure that it is compliant with the EPA's regulations concerning the storage of hazardous materials?
FAQs.answer: Stores selling pesticides, insecticides and other dangerous materials ensure any defunct product is disposed of according to safety standards. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires that all pesticides distributed or sold in the United States be registered.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Nursery and garden stores' profit remain narrow as the industry is highly fragmented with high levels of competition.

FAQs.question: How have volatile input prices affected profit margins over the past year?
FAQs.answer: Key inputs like the price of fertilizer and fuel can impact profitability.

FAQs.question: Does your company have good relations with its suppliers?
Ability to control stock on hand
FAQs.answer: Offering a wide array of plants and flowers is essential for a company's competitiveness. Consumers will feel more confident visiting retailers who can consistently have the things they are looking for in stock.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a specialty or area of expertise?
What proportion of revenue is allocated to advertising and promotional activities?
Having a clear market position
FAQs.answer: A clear market position enables stores to emphasize their area of expertise (e.g. rose nurseries) and differentiate themselves from their competition.

FAQs.question: Is your store located in an easily accessible area with pedestrian traffic? Is your company an area experiencing population growth?
FAQs.answer: Stores can maximize exposure to consumers by being close to key markets. The industry also benefits from new residential construction as these projects require plants and other industry products for landscaping purposes. Being in an area with an expanding population can prove beneficial to stores.

FAQs.question: Which of your products are the most affected by fluctuating levels of private spending on home improvements?
FAQs.answer: When consumers undertake home improvement projects, industry revenue grows as both do-it-yourself and professional customers purchase project materials from industry stores.

FAQs.question: In what ways have new housing starts impacted your company?
FAQs.answer: The number of housing starts in a year can significantly influence industry revenue. If the number of new houses increases, there is likely to be a boost in demand for the industry as the outdoor spaces of new homes require landscaping.

FAQs.question: How do changes in per capita disposable income impact your company?
FAQs.answer: When household income levels increase, consumers can afford better quality and a more extensive range of nursery stock. Conversely, a contraction in income levels causes consumers to defer purchases of these products because they are nonessential.
